titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the War Poster Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by William E. Brown and Christopher Geissler
titlestmt.sponsor: World War Two-era posters in this collection were digitized with support from the Yale College Class of 1945W.

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:20

did.unittitle: War poster collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The collection consists of posters published in nations involved in World War I, 1914-1918, the Spanish Civil War, and World War II, 1939-1945. Great Britain, the United States, France, Germany, Italy, Russia, Canada, Australia, Ireland and other nations are represented through posters depicting such diverse topics as recruitment, enlistment, conservation, war loans, civilian service, home relief, foreign relief and propaganda messages. Posters issued by government agencies, social organizations, and private concerns are included.

langmaterial.language: The materials are in English, French, German, Greek, Hungarian, Italian, Polish, Russian, Spanish, Turkish, Welsh, and Yiddish.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Lafon Allen, 1937, and several others; transferred from the Medical Historical Library, 1990, and the Librarian's Office, 1995; Library purchase, 2004; transferred from the Kaplanoff Librarian for American History, 2016.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Accession 2007-M-065 is restricted pending conservation treatment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: War Poster Collection (MS 671). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Approximately 200 posters from series I and II are available in digital form through Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database (MADID).
William Mullally Collection available on microfilm (2 reels, 35mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University, at cost. Order no. HM157.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The War Poster Collection is a composite of several individual donations and library purchases, accumulated from the 1920s through the 1980s, and 2004. Individual donations, such as that of Lafon Allen, are identified within the War Poster Collection, as single collections themselves.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The original item-level index to series I was produced using the FAMULUS word processing program and later converted to an Excel spreadsheet and encoded in EAD. A small quantity of World War I posters from the collections of Simon Brett, Paul Jean Gaston Darrott, and William Mullally were not originally itemized or indexed. In May 2014 these items were indexed while encoding the finding aid. However, they were not assigned item numbers. Thirty posters from the Allen Collection had also not previously been described at the item level. During the creation of the encoded finding aid, these posters were described at the item level and the original codes and numerical identifiers were retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of posters disseminated by and published in nations involved in World War I, 1914-1918, the Spanish Civil War, and World War II, 1939-1945. Great Britain, the United States, France, Germany, Italy, Russia, Canada, Australia, Ireland and other nations are represented through posters depicting such diverse topics as recruitment, enlistment, conservation, war loans, civilian service, home relief, foreign relief and propaganda messages. Posters issued by government agencies, social organizations, and private concerns are included.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in three series: I. World War I, 1914- 1918, II. Spanish Civil War, 1936-1939, III World War II, 1939-1945, and three additions.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: For an index of artists represented in this collection, please consult theIndex of Artists.
For an index of subject terms used to describe this collection, please consult theSubject Terms Index.

did.unittitle: World War I

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, World War I, 1914-1918, contains approximately 3,000 posters produced during this war.

The information provided for each poster is as follows. 1. An item number comprised of a one-letter designation representing the individual collection (which forms part of the larger poster collection) in which the item is arranged: A - Lafon Allen Collection, W - Charles B. Whittelsey Collection, Y - Yale Library Collection; a two- letter designation for the country under which the poster is arranged within the individual collection: AU (Austria), BE (Belgium), CA (Canada), CZ (Czechoslovakia), FR (France), GB (Great Britain), GE (Germany), GR (Greece), HO (Holland), HU (Hungary), IN (India), IT (Italy), MX (Mexico), PO (Poland), RU (Soviet Union), SW (Switzerland), US (United States); and a four-character numeral designation for a poster within its collection/country code. Example: ABE001. 2. Title. The title appearing on the poster. Use of an ellipsis ["…"] signifies that the title continues beyond what is provided here. 3. Date. The year, month, and day (when known) for publication of the poster. 4. Size. The physical dimensions of the poster, in inches with fractional measurements rounded off to the higher number. 5. Language. The language of the poster's text. 6. Artist. The name of the artist who created the poster. 7. Place of publication. The country in which (or for which) the poster was produced. This may differ from the "Country Code" as in the case of Great Britain posters) which include items created for and in Australia, Canada, and Ireland. 8. Notes. Comments about the item including number of pieces or description of an untitled image.

did.unittitle: World War II

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, World War II, 1939-1945, contains approximately 240 posters. They are arranged by country of origin. Nations such as China, France, Great Britain, the Soviet Union, and the United States are represented in this series. Also included are a few posters from the immediate post-war period.

Additional Spanish Civil War posters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession comprises posters and a broadside from the Spanish Civil War, all in support of the Republican faction. Creators of the posters include Partido de Izquierda Republicana, Asociación de Amigos de la Unión Soviética, Juventudes Socialistas Unificados, and Comité Central del Partido Comunista. Materials date from 1936 to 1938.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
